question: If speaker of Lok Sabha wrongly identifies and certifies an ordinary bill as money bill, then which among the following would follow?
option1: The decision of the speaker shall be challenged with a petition in the Supreme Court
option2: The Bill will be sent to the Joint Committee of Houses
option3: The bill will be deemed lapsed
explanation: A Money Bill can be introduced in Lok Sabha only. If any question arises whether a Bill is a Money Bill or not, the decision of Speaker thereon is final. The Speaker is under no obligation to consult any one in coming to a decision or in giving his certificate that a Bill is a Money Bill. The certificate of the Speaker to the effect that a Bill is a Money Bill, is to be endorsed and signed by him when it is transmitted to Rajya Sabha and also when it is presented to the President for his assent. The Speakerâ€™s certificate on a Money Bill once given is final and cannot be challenged. A Money Bill cannot be referred to a Joint Committee of the Houses.
